byline.contributor: Nicholas Casey reported from New York. Julia Symmes Cobb contributed from Bogotá, Colombia, and Paula Duran from Mexico City.
byline.original: By KIRK SEMPLE and NICHOLAS CASEY

abstract: Colombian leaders are left wondering why citizens voted down peace deal with Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, despite polls that had previously shown wide margin of victory for deal in referendum; many citizens saw deal as too lenient on rebels, particularly in wake of successful military operations against rebel group.
lead_paragraph: Months of polling had predicted a wide margin of victory for the agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest rebel group.
snippet: Months of polling had predicted a wide margin of victory for the agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest rebel group....

headline.main: Deep Scars and Complacency Defeated Colombia’s Peace Deal
headline.print_headline: Colombia Deal Fell to Turnout and Old Scars
